carousels.name: what-is-an-ai-wrapper
carousels.description: Defining what AI wrappers are and how they work — the thin layer of AI over existing models

slides.topText: AI wrappers are applications that have a thin layer of AI over them.
slides.bottomText: They don't have their own proprietary model for AI.

slides.topText: OpenAI has GPT-4 — they trained it, they invested resources.
slides.bottomText: Google has Gemini. Anthropic has Claude. Meta has Llama.

slides.topText: AI wrappers are the companies who access these models
slides.bottomText: and then build an application layer over them.

slides.topText: They don't own the models themselves.
slides.bottomText: They have no way to train their own models.

slides.topText: What they're doing is making an API request —
slides.bottomText: requesting data from models that OpenAI or Google owns.

slides.topText: They receive that data back into their application
slides.bottomText: and serve it up to the clients.

slides.topText: An example would be chatbots.
slides.bottomText: Or those essay-writing AI companies that say 'we help you write copy.'

carousels.name: competing-on-prompts
carousels.description: AI wrapper companies compete on prompt engineering — subject matter expertise is the real differentiator

slides.topText: AI wrapper companies showed up in hordes
slides.bottomText: during the generative AI era of 2021 to 2022.

slides.topText: Almost every AI company is technically a wrapper
slides.bottomText: but it is solving a specialized use case.

slides.topText: Their value proposition is their prompt engineering —
slides.bottomText: how well their prompts are to the AI model.

slides.topText: If you're choosing between two essay-writing AIs —
slides.bottomText: you'd pick whichever one writes a better essay. They're competing on how well they prompt the same model.

slides.topText: Being a good prompter means being a subject matter expert.
slides.bottomText: An animator knows the exact terminologies — cinematography, VFX, different cuts.

slides.topText: These experts can templatize the prompt —
slides.bottomText: serve up a form where you fill in 'I want this filter, this effect.'

slides.topText: You wouldn't have thought about these terms as a layperson.
slides.bottomText: That's how a subject matter expert adds real value to an AI wrapper.

carousels.name: danger-of-not-owning-your-model
carousels.description: The risks of building on someone else's AI model — pricing, opacity, and the threat of being easily replicated

slides.topText: There's a long-term sustainability factor to think about.
slides.bottomText: The moment OpenAI or Anthropic decides 'we're not sharing our models anymore' —

slides.topText: What can they do? Exactly.
slides.bottomText: Or they share their models but you're subject to their price increases.

slides.topText: APIs are cheap now because they want everyone to use them.
slides.bottomText: But once they increase the price per API call — your entire pricing model changes.

slides.topText: You're basically beholden to whatever the model owners decide.
slides.bottomText: And it's also very opaque to you.

slides.topText: You don't know how they train the model.
slides.bottomText: You don't know the existing biases. There are no standards enforcing transparency.

slides.topText: The scary part is when your only value is the prompt.
slides.bottomText: Somebody could come in and steal the same idea — it's so easily stolen.

slides.topText: In the startup community saturated with AI wrapper companies,
slides.bottomText: that's what investors are wary of. There's talk of an AI bubble.

carousels.name: data-ethics-pivot
carousels.description: A cautionary tale about an AI wrapper company that pivoted to a proprietary model by secretly harvesting user data

slides.topText: I have a story of a company that used to be an AI wrapper
slides.bottomText: but they're trying to pivot by building their own model.

slides.topText: How are they going to collect data to build their own model?
slides.bottomText: It's tricky. They started using users' data without being transparent.

slides.topText: They told users 'We're training our own model now'
slides.bottomText: but essentially they were reading users' message history and all their information.

slides.topText: When they released the model, users asked 'How did you build this?'
slides.bottomText: 'Oh, from opt-in users' data.' Opt-in.

slides.topText: In the small terms and conditions, you're essentially opting in.
slides.bottomText: As users, we just have to be vigilant in how companies use our data.

slides.topText: These terms and conditions are designed to make you feel so burdened
slides.bottomText: that you just accept — they don't offer a way for you to negotiate.

slides.topText: It's either you accept our terms or you don't use the app.
slides.bottomText: There are no regulations to make terms and conditions negotiable. And that's a problem.
